item.title: Metacognition Habit
item.description: Mental Habit: Metacognitive Thinking in Engineering Education 1. Description and Theoretical Framework Definition and Importance Metacognitive thinking—often referred to as reflection—is the mental habit of being aware of, monitoring, and intentionally improving one’s own thinking and learning processes.

item.title: Opportunity Habit
item.description: Mental Habit: Opportunity-Oriented Thinking in Engineering Education 1. Description and Theoretical Framework Definition and Importance Opportunity-oriented thinking is a mental habit rooted in the proactive pursuit of potential.

item.title: Intellectual Humility Habit
item.description: Mental Habit: Intellectual Humility in Engineering Education 1. Description and Theoretical Framework Definition and Importance Intellectual humility is a mental habit characterized by the recognition of one’s intellectual limitations and an openness to alternative perspectives.

item.title: Connections Habit
item.description: Mental Habit: Connected Thinking in Engineering Education Connected thinking can become a mental habit. While mental habits are widely recognized as different than mindset, authors have linked mental habits and the development of entrepreneurial mindset.

item.title: Creating Value Habit
item.description: Mental Habit: Value-Creation Thinking in Engineering Education Figure attributed to valohai.com/blog/managing-ai-products/ Try the game to add an INNOVATION force among other ...

item.title: Agency Habit
item.description: Mental Habit: Action-Orientation and Agency in Engineering Education 1. Description and Theoretical Framework Definition and Importance Action-orientation and agency is a mental habit characterized by a proactive stance toward problem-solving, an internalized locus of control, and the ability to find or create resources to overcome obstacles.

item.title: Impact Habit
item.description: Mental Habit: Impact Thinking in Engineering Education 1. Description and Theoretical Framework Definition and Importance Impact thinking is a mental habit characterized by the ability to anticipate, analyze, and evaluate the potential long-term and multifaceted consequences of engineering decisions and designs.

item.title: Curiosity Habit
item.description: Mental Habit: Curiosity in Engineering Education 1. Description and Theoretical Framework Definition and Importance Curiosity is a mental habit characterized by a strong desire to explore, investigate, and learn that drives individuals to ask questions, seek new information, and develop deeper understanding.

item.title: Welcome to Quartz 4
item.description: EM Stuff Quartz is a fast, batteries-included static-site generator that transforms Markdown content into fully functional websites. Thousands of students, developers, and teachers are already using Quartz to publish personal notes, websites, and digital gardens to the web.
